Not many days ago, an elderly emigrant

 to the county of Washtenaw, discovered,

 not far from his domicil, what he consider

 ed to be the tracks of a panther: and im-

 mediately came to the praiseworthy resolu- ton of destroying the feIocious animal

 Sixteen active and courageous young

 woodsmen were soon invited to hunt the

 animal; and when they assembled with

 their rifles, &c.~ it was decided that the

 woods in which it had taken shelter, should

 be surrounded by the party, who were to

 approach towards tho centre. The ma

 nnuvre succeeded-the panther was driv- en to tree, around the foot of which, the

 marty. elated with their success. soon gath cred. The angry animallooked down upon his pursuers, his glaring eye-balis seeming to shoot tremor into the stoutest heart.- | In moment more, several balls entered his body-but he fell not-the death pang lhad fixed his terrible nails deep into the

 tree, and there he hung, as if in mockery ofthe hunters and their rifles. At length, a daring young man offered to climb the

 tree, and force the panther to quit his | hold. fj,stIgGg lfI ->--~~,~.,.J s P. ..s.

' SPANISH PRIDE AND EcoNoMY..-The fol- following is what MT. Ory has related to me during the visits he has made here :: when expecting to go to Spain he heard that the Duke d'Alba had sent to sell a plate to the amout of 10, 900 crowns, he called on him, aud said that he did not offer him any of the money he, was, taking 10 the king.of Spain, that prince being too much in. want of it but that he begged the duke would at once accept thousand louis d'ors, and afterwards tie forty thousand crowns, which he knew How to get back from his catholic majesty. The duke re- piled, that he vaouldabe very sorry to ask the king his master for money. at a time like the present; and that he would most willingly give him some, if he had it :, that at all events, he felt hurt at the offer of MT. Orry flor as his wife had still some jewels left, when these eswere gone, they could live on chocolate, of which they had stock for two years.-Secret Cores.

From he FOREST SANCTUARY, POEM 6v Mrs. HEMANs, recently published in Boston. A fearful thing that love and death may dwell In the same world !-She faded on-and I- Blind to the last, there needed death to tell My trusting soul that she could fade to die; Yet, ere she parted, had marked change But it breathed hope-twas beautiful, though strange: A Something of gladness in the melody, or her low voice, and in her words a flight Of airy thought-alas too pcrilously bright ]! And a clear sparkle n her glance, yet wild, And quick, and eager, like the flashing gaze Of some all wondering and awakening child, That first the giories of the earth surveys. How could it thus deceive me !-she had worn .1 ..i.. IF. .. .. Around her, like the dewy msts of morn. A peasive tenderness through happiest days. And soft world of dreams had seern'd to lie Still in her dark, and deep, and spiritual eye. And could hope in that strange fire ;--she

 died,

 She died, with all its lustre on her mein The day was melting from the waters wide, And through its long bright hours her thoughts

 had been, t@-.- ., so- Itseem'd with restless and unwonted yearning, To Spain's blue skies and dark sierias turning; For her fond words were all of vintage scene, And Towering myrtle & sweet citron's breath, Oh with what vivid hucs life comes back

 oft on death And from her lips mountain songs of old, h wild faint snatches, itfully had sprung; Songs of the orange bower, the Moorish hold, The 's Rio Verde." on her soul that hung, And thence fow'd forth.-But now the sun

 was low

 And watching by my side ifs last red glow, That ever stills the heart, once more she sung Her own soft " Ora Mater r'--and the sound Wps even like loves farewell-so mournfully

 profound.

 The boy had droppd to slumber at our feet: -"And have lull'd him to his smiling rest Once more" :" she said,-I raised him-it was

 sweet, .... Yet sad. to see the peafect calm which bless'd His look that hour !-for now her voice grew

 weak; at 3lt.. ...uf. f.'.. And on the fowery crimson of his cheek. With her white fpsa ns.lOng kiss she press'd, Yet light to wake him not-Then sank her

 head ,...t'

 Against my bursting heart; What did clasp; ' the dead E..r., ,-

YOUNG LADIES' ALRUHs.

thrown to the earth, which he no sooner touched than the dogs went in upon him, and having revenged themselves flor the trouble which they had been put to in the 1 chase, they walked surlily aside, and per- ; nlitted their masters to approach and view the prostrate, yet terrible foe. The son of the old gentleman who had discovered the track, first came near, and taking the animal

 by the tail, he raised it at arms length, and { having examined it for moment, he called to his father-" Dad," said he, 'sthis is our old cat ?''--" Poh," said the old man, that can't be-'tis twice as large as our old at.''-" Look for yourself" said the son. The thing was then subjected to the old gentleman's examination, who was re-

 luctantly forced to admit |" that it was our old cat.,

 Numerous anecdotes are extant of the

 dauntless enterprise, and headlong valour of Gen. Israel Putnam. We recollect to

 have heard one from a. agentleman of an ad- joining town, who was attached to Mr.

 Putnam's body-guard, during the Revolu- ton. We have seen it in print, and every circumstance relating to the General is in- teresting to the people of his native State we annex it.

 In the French and Indian War of 1755, Putnam, then a captain, and brother off cer, were sent to reconnoitre the camp of the enemy. Impelled by an ungovernable anxiety to ascertain the precise situation of the foe they approached so near their lines as to be discovered. Immediate and swift pursuit was commenced by par ty of about 20 Indians. The Americans were young and active, and for the first mile they gained on their adversaries, but knowing well the capacity of the savages for continuing and even increasing their speed ,and fearful of being ultimately over- taken, they ascending lofty pine, and concealed themselves among its branches. It was nearly dark, and they were effeetu- ally hid from observation, while the move- ments of the Indians were distinctly visi-. ble. They collected around the tree, ut tering horrid yells, and searching in vain for the fugitives. While Rogers, the com- panion of Putnam, was silent in breath- less suspense, Putnam changed his posi- ton, so as to have fair aim at his ene- mics, cooked his musket, and prepared to fire. Rogers saw the temerity of the act, and said in. a whisper. .y -..-~ -..

 "Hold, Putnam, for the love of Heaven 1!

 you cannot kill more than one of the sava-

 ges, and our destruction will be inevita- ble! echoed Putnam. with his usual as- servation, and in a tone far too vociferous for their dangerous situation; {" what do cares for thatl Heavens curse blight the Y ho1f pF them. :" .'" And it was only at the earnest and repeat ed entreaties of Rogers, that he was in- duced to forego his plan, and remain quiet until the savages had retired, when they descended the tree, and returned to the camp in safety.-Mid. Gas.

 SUPPORT OF THE pooR.-Thc Salem Ob- server, noticing the proceedings of this town relative to the support ofPaupers on a farm, observes "that the success which has attended the poor establishment in Sa- lem has induced some others iyadiciously to follow their example "--it being gener- ally supposed that farm if it employ paul. pers must be profitable, whereas it IS gen. orally otherwise. Few of our citizens we UCIIGVCs OA hOAiDS d farm profitable to the town by way ofin- come-it may possibly diminish the ex- pences for the support of the poor, and dis courage the vice of idleness.

 We are informed that the town of Weare in this State, in March, 1925, ad- opted the mode of supporting their poor at the proper charge and expense of the town im one family.-The contractor is bound to support all persons then known and all others whom the Selectmen shall decide are paupers from time to time within the year, and notify the contractor thereof in writing, who is deemed. chargeable within 24 hours after such notice ;.no expense a. rising without the limits of the town ac- crucs to the contractor ;; but he is isdecent- ly to inter all who may decease within his contract. For the first year the contract was for $40; for 1926, the contract was for S397 and for the present year it is but S2OO. NH. Jour. .. .,.4,;.

 Point of Honor.-One n5orning, while we were in Paris, our lacquey de place did not appear as usual. Breakfast passed, the carriage drove to the door,still no lacquey, and Colonel Clcaveland, in a passion, had

From the Monthly and ENrOpeGn MGgaztne. On! what is pleasure, in whose chase Life's one brief day is made,a race

 Ofvanity and lightnessn J3 A star, to gaze on whose bright crown, We wait until the sun goes down, And find, when it has OCT us shone, No warmth in all it's brightness. And what is Friendship? That false fow'r Which spreads its leaves at daylight's hour,

 And closes them at eve; Opening its petals to the light, Sweet-breathing while the sun shines bright But shut to those who, midst the night Of doubt and darkness, grieye. And what is Fame the smile that stays, The cup in which sweet poison plays;

 At best, the Aowery wreath, That twip'd around the victim's head When, midst sweet Aow'rs around it spread, And ssharps and timbrels' sounds, 'tis led

 Melodiously, to death. And what are Hopes Gay butterflies That on the breath of fancy rise,

 Where'er the sun- beam lures them; For ever, ever on the wing, ... MockingS jour faint steps following. And if at last caught, perishing

 In the grasp that secures them., And our affections, what are they? Oh! blossoms smiling on the spray,

 All beauty, and all sweetness But which the canker may lay bare, Or rude hands from the branches tear, 5. Or bIighting winds leave whitening there,

 Sad types of mortal feetness. And what is Life itself? A sail With sometimes an suspicious gale,

 And some bright sunbea,ns round it, But oft'ner amidst iempests cast, The low'ring sky, the bowling blast,T And 'whelm'd beneath the wave at last,

 Where never plunmet sounded. 4 -..a~. H. N.

 CURIOUS ExHIBETIoN.--On n entering Moe- ana, we were witnesses to rather curious exhibition. should first mention, that the Persians are in the habit of sleeping on flat roofs oftheir houses, during the sum- mer months. Day was just breaking when we arrived. As the houses of the poor are generally not more than eight feet high, we had full view of nearly the whole popu- lation in bed many were asleep some few were awake others were getting out of bed, to make their morning toilettes. The scene was highly entertaining, and brought to mind the story of Le Diable Boiteux, unroofing the houses for the grat- ification of Don Cleofas. Jour- neg from India to England.

 A RUSSIAN AMAZON On dismounting at village near Darkee, my stirrup was held by fair and handsome-looking per- son, who proved to be female. Admira- ton of military life had induced her to deprive herself of her fair tresses, and to wear the dress of a man, preparatory as she said, to offering her services to the Emperor as a soldier. Hearing was on the way, she told me that, if she had been a little older, she e'would have accompanied me. I told her that she would be reject ed, from her feminine appearance; but she said she would cut off her breasts, when eversfhey were too large for conceaIment. On taking leave of this little amazon, I gave her an old aiguillette, which she ac- cepted with great delight, and strutted off with it on her shoulder, to the no small a. mazement of the villagers.-Ibid.

Dublin, of a female passenger who was dressed in sailors clothes, and passed by the name of William Brown. The officers. who took her into custody, acted from in- formation of the disguise, which they SUD- posed might have been done to conceal some theft. The sailor was conveyed to prison. From some enquiries, the house where Brown lodged was discovered, the proprietor of which referred the officers to the master of the brig Laura, of N. York, as Knowing all about her. Her story, as well as could be collected, appears to he as follows Her father is merchant in London. About 3 years ago she lief his house to follow her lover, who was the mate of vessel in the North American trade, and hearing he had sailed for St. Johns, she came to Liverpool and to ok passage for that port. On arriving at St. Johns, she discovered that the vessel had gone to Quebec, tilither she went, and there learned that her lover was drowned in his passage up the St. Lawrence. She immediately determined to become sai- Tor fer his sake, and assuming the garb of a man, engaged as cook and steward to the master of a vessel to London, with whom she remained upwards of 12 months.- The next vessel she joined, and in which she also served upwards of 12 months, some weeks back, brought her to Liver pool, but the master, suspecting her sex, extorted from her the secret, and wished her to remain with him, but she would net consent, and she was about to proceed to Ireland. While in prison she said her name was Selina Augusta Hamilton. She is said to be a complete sailor, taking her grog and using tobacco like other tars.- She states that she will have G4,OOO at her disposal when she becomes of age, (she is not yet 19) and intends to equip a vessel and take command. She was brought up for examination on the 10th Feb. at the Town Hall, when it appeared that her ar- rest was caused by the captain of the Lau- ra. The girl refused to tell the magistrate, Alderman Bourne, her fathers name she said she could see no. necessity for it: she said she was a sailor now, and such inten- ded to remain. MT. Duflrey, of the Lau- ra, wished the Magistrate to place her in his charge, that he might restore her to her father. At this sIre gave him look of surprise, and then remarked to the magis- trate, that she had made choice ofher pre- sent mode of life, and meant to pursue it. The magistrate discharged her.

 From the American Quarterly Review.

 ROMAN AMPHITHEATREs.

 Our author next brings us acqainted witII the aniphitheatres of the Romans, and pre- sents highly interesting picture eff the man. ner in which the " masters of the world" were recreated by the destruction of wild beasts, in the'circus. It was in the year 251, B. 0. that elephants were first introduced into the cireus,' by Metellus, berg those recently mentioned as captured in Sicily From this period, (says our author,) the passion for public ex- hibitions and combats of wild beasts, spread not only in Italy, but throughout the Roman empire in all the provinces" Such was the general rage, that scarcely a. fixed military station was without its circus or amphithea-' tre of turf or timber.

 The circular form of the amphitheatre was changed ny Julius Cesar for the elliptical, and thereafter such buildings were called theatres for hunting. They were also used for the combats of gladiators, as their acccommoda- tions were so much better than the circular buidings.-They were still however called circus, as often as by other names. Some were little more than notvral Ualleys, with benches cut in the surrounding hills others were elliptical excavations, with benches of turf like that near Sandwich in Kent; some were partly excavated, and partly construc- ted with masonry, like the amphitheatre at Caerlon in Britain. There were also amphi- theatres constructed to hold water for the combat of aquatic and amphibious animals. When these buildings were of timber, they were erected orremOved as occasion required. CapiOdorus states that Vespasian spent as much on one as would have built capital ci- ty; and Martial relates that Roman citizens crowded from all parts of the empire td be present at these exhibitions. .l

 The amphithcatres were supplied with wild beasts from the remotest provinces Of the ena- plre, and with :he most rare and singular ais- imals. without regard to their size or ferociots nature. Lions, tigers, bears. and hyenas, were brought, in what appears almost incredible numbers; the elephant, rhinoceros, hippopo- tamus. and camelOpard; stags and deer of every description; zebras, wild asses. ostrich and even the crocodile of the Nile, were all produced at different times & in various nnnn- bers to be exhibited IS objects of curiosity. to be hunted by the people in the theatre. or slaughtered in the combat with each other.

 The diversions were of three kinds In the first the anfphitheatre was cOnserted into a lrnslrespDtatiOn cf a natural f0fNsf hv 9neMuN Of

SOW they shall reap-that youth, the ssa- son of improvement, is passing rapidly a. way-as rapidly when we are idle, as whel, engaged that future life will be happy or miserable, joyous or sorrowful, according to the improvement of youth, how vastly different would they spend their time Re- member. youth is the season of improve. ment, and let every setting sun find thee, wiser by some work of usefulnes than when 1t arose. sg

MELLEN, Sir--the cause of humanity siessassds Of me tn give the following state nent: My wife had for six years been in a decline and pronounced by her Physicians tn be in consumptiye state. and was attended by a severe pain in her side, with Cough & difficulty of breathing. She was reduced so low as to he unable to get from her bed to the fire without aid. All hopes of her recovery had long been given up. <, In this situation, was prevailed upon, as a last possible resort, vet without any hopes of success, to make aIsc of" Anderson's Cough Drops." She com mcnced the use of them in February last and after using two bottles, to the astonshment of all, in the month of May following the health of my wife was entirely restored, and since which, her health and strength were perhaps never better. Feeling deep interest that the public in general may resort to the same remedy, when their friends and relatives are apparently, or evidently on the brink of the Yon are at liberty to publishthe above.

 am respectfully, &c. .-r.

 This is to certify that the subscriber was brought very low by splitting blood, attended with cough and catarrh. and that nothing afforded me real relief until commenced ta- king Anderson's Cough Drops, the use of which were the means in the hand of God of restoring me again to a comfortable state of health. -... -4

Point oJf Honor.-One nsorning, while

 we were in Paris, our lacquey de place did

 not appear as usual. Breakfast passed, the carriage drove to the door,still no lacquey, and Colonel Clcaveland, in passion, had sent to engage another, when, panting with exertion, the gentleman appeared. "He

 was very sorry-he begged ten thousand

 pardons--he had hoped to have got his little affairs over sooner. " .' Your affairs, you scoundrel, what are your affairs to us- Do you think we are to sit waiting here, while you are running after your own affairs r. "Pardonnezmoi Monsieur" said the lacquey with. low bow, and laying his hand upon his heart, l" but it was an affair of honour !' and the man had actu- ally been fighting duel with swords, with

 another lacquey, in consequence ot some quarrel while waiting for us at the French

 to the county of Washtenaw, discovered,

 not far from his domicil, what he consider

 ed to be the tracks of a panther: and im-

 mediately came to the praiseworthy resolu- ton of destroying the feIocious animal

 Sixteen active and courageous young

 woodsmen were soon invited to hunt the

 animal; and when they assembled with

 their rifles, &c.~ it was decided that the

 woods in which it had taken shelter, should

 be surrounded by the party, who were to

 approach towards tho centre. The ma

 nnuvre succeeded-the panther was driv- en to tree, around the foot of which, the

 marty. elated with their success. soon gath cred. The angry animallooked down upon his pursuers, his glaring eye-balis seeming to shoot tremor into the stoutest heart.- | In moment more, several balls entered his body-but he fell not-the death pang lhad fixed his terrible nails deep into the

full articles.article: ' SPANISH PRIDE AND EcoNoMY..-The fol- following is what MT. Ory has related to me during the visits he has made here :: when expecting to go to Spain he heard that the Duke d'Alba had sent to sell a plate to the amout of 10, 900 crowns, he called on him, aud said that he did not offer him any of the money he, was, taking 10 the king.of Spain, that prince being too much in. want of it but that he begged the duke would at once accept thousand louis d'ors, and afterwards tie forty thousand crowns, which he knew How to get back from his catholic majesty. The duke re- piled, that he vaouldabe very sorry to ask the king his master for money. at a time like the present; and that he would most willingly give him some, if he had it :, that at all events, he felt hurt at the offer of MT. Orry flor as his wife had still some jewels left, when these eswere gone, they could live on chocolate, of which they had stock for two years.-Secret Cores.

From he FOREST SANCTUARY, POEM 6v Mrs. HEMANs, recently published in Boston. A fearful thing that love and death may dwell In the same world !-She faded on-and I- Blind to the last, there needed death to tell My trusting soul that she could fade to die; Yet, ere she parted, had marked change But it breathed hope-twas beautiful, though strange: A Something of gladness in the melody, or her low voice, and in her words a flight Of airy thought-alas too pcrilously bright ]! And a clear sparkle n her glance, yet wild, And quick, and eager, like the flashing gaze Of some all wondering and awakening child, That first the giories of the earth surveys. How could it thus deceive me !-she had worn .1 ..i.. IF. .. .. Around her, like the dewy msts of morn. A peasive tenderness through happiest days. And soft world of dreams had seern'd to lie Still in her dark, and deep, and spiritual eye. And could hope in that strange fire ;--she

 died,

 She died, with all its lustre on her mein The day was melting from the waters wide, And through its long bright hours her thoughts

 had been, t@-.- ., so- Itseem'd with restless and unwonted yearning, To Spain's blue skies and dark sierias turning; For her fond words were all of vintage scene, And Towering myrtle & sweet citron's breath, Oh with what vivid hucs life comes back

 oft on death And from her lips mountain songs of old, h wild faint snatches, itfully had sprung; Songs of the orange bower, the Moorish hold, The 's Rio Verde." on her soul that hung, And thence fow'd forth.-But now the sun

 was low

 And watching by my side ifs last red glow, That ever stills the heart, once more she sung Her own soft " Ora Mater r'--and the sound Wps even like loves farewell-so mournfully

 profound.

 The boy had droppd to slumber at our feet: -"And have lull'd him to his smiling rest Once more" :" she said,-I raised him-it was

 sweet, .... Yet sad. to see the peafect calm which bless'd His look that hour !-for now her voice grew

 weak; at 3lt.. ...uf. f.'.. And on the fowery crimson of his cheek. With her white fpsa ns.lOng kiss she press'd, Yet light to wake him not-Then sank her

 head ,...t'

 Against my bursting heart; What did clasp; ' the dead E..r., ,-

 Numerous anecdotes are extant of the

 dauntless enterprise, and headlong valour of Gen. Israel Putnam. We recollect to

 have heard one from a. agentleman of an ad- joining town, who was attached to Mr.

 Putnam's body-guard, during the Revolu- ton. We have seen it in print, and every circumstance relating to the General is in- teresting to the people of his native State we annex it.

 In the French and Indian War of 1755, Putnam, then a captain, and brother off cer, were sent to reconnoitre the camp of the enemy. Impelled by an ungovernable anxiety to ascertain the precise situation of the foe they approached so near their lines as to be discovered. Immediate and swift pursuit was commenced by par ty of about 20 Indians. The Americans were young and active, and for the first mile they gained on their adversaries, but knowing well the capacity of the savages for continuing and even increasing their speed ,and fearful of being ultimately over- taken, they ascending lofty pine, and concealed themselves among its branches. It was nearly dark, and they were effeetu- ally hid from observation, while the move- ments of the Indians were distinctly visi-. ble. They collected around the tree, ut tering horrid yells, and searching in vain for the fugitives. While Rogers, the com- panion of Putnam, was silent in breath- less suspense, Putnam changed his posi- ton, so as to have fair aim at his ene- mics, cooked his musket, and prepared to fire. Rogers saw the temerity of the act, and said in. a whisper. .y -..-~ -..

 "Hold, Putnam, for the love of Heaven 1!

 you cannot kill more than one of the sava-

 ges, and our destruction will be inevita- ble! echoed Putnam. with his usual as- servation, and in a tone far too vociferous for their dangerous situation; {" what do cares for thatl Heavens curse blight the Y ho1f pF them. :" .'" And it was only at the earnest and repeat ed entreaties of Rogers, that he was in- duced to forego his plan, and remain quiet until the savages had retired, when they descended the tree, and returned to the camp in safety.-Mid. Gas.

 SUPPORT OF THE pooR.-Thc Salem Ob- server, noticing the proceedings of this town relative to the support ofPaupers on a farm, observes "that the success which has attended the poor establishment in Sa- lem has induced some others iyadiciously to follow their example "--it being gener- ally supposed that farm if it employ paul. pers must be profitable, whereas it IS gen. orally otherwise. Few of our citizens we UCIIGVCs OA hOAiDS d farm profitable to the town by way ofin- come-it may possibly diminish the ex- pences for the support of the poor, and dis courage the vice of idleness.

 We are informed that the town of Weare in this State, in March, 1925, ad- opted the mode of supporting their poor at the proper charge and expense of the town im one family.-The contractor is bound to support all persons then known and all others whom the Selectmen shall decide are paupers from time to time within the year, and notify the contractor thereof in writing, who is deemed. chargeable within 24 hours after such notice ;.no expense a. rising without the limits of the town ac- crucs to the contractor ;; but he is isdecent- ly to inter all who may decease within his contract. For the first year the contract was for $40; for 1926, the contract was for S397 and for the present year it is but S2OO. NH. Jour. .. .,.4,;.

 Point of Honor.-One n5orning, while we were in Paris, our lacquey de place did not appear as usual. Breakfast passed, the carriage drove to the door,still no lacquey, and Colonel Clcaveland, in a passion, had

From the Monthly and ENrOpeGn MGgaztne. On! what is pleasure, in whose chase Life's one brief day is made,a race

 Ofvanity and lightnessn J3 A star, to gaze on whose bright crown, We wait until the sun goes down, And find, when it has OCT us shone, No warmth in all it's brightness. And what is Friendship? That false fow'r Which spreads its leaves at daylight's hour,

 And closes them at eve; Opening its petals to the light, Sweet-breathing while the sun shines bright But shut to those who, midst the night Of doubt and darkness, grieye. And what is Fame the smile that stays, The cup in which sweet poison plays;

 At best, the Aowery wreath, That twip'd around the victim's head When, midst sweet Aow'rs around it spread, And ssharps and timbrels' sounds, 'tis led

 Melodiously, to death. And what are Hopes Gay butterflies That on the breath of fancy rise,

 Where'er the sun- beam lures them; For ever, ever on the wing, ... MockingS jour faint steps following. And if at last caught, perishing

 In the grasp that secures them., And our affections, what are they? Oh! blossoms smiling on the spray,

 All beauty, and all sweetness But which the canker may lay bare, Or rude hands from the branches tear, 5. Or bIighting winds leave whitening there,

 Sad types of mortal feetness. And what is Life itself? A sail With sometimes an suspicious gale,

 And some bright sunbea,ns round it, But oft'ner amidst iempests cast, The low'ring sky, the bowling blast,T And 'whelm'd beneath the wave at last,

 Where never plunmet sounded. 4 -..a~. H. N.

 CURIOUS ExHIBETIoN.--On n entering Moe- ana, we were witnesses to rather curious exhibition. should first mention, that the Persians are in the habit of sleeping on flat roofs oftheir houses, during the sum- mer months. Day was just breaking when we arrived. As the houses of the poor are generally not more than eight feet high, we had full view of nearly the whole popu- lation in bed many were asleep some few were awake others were getting out of bed, to make their morning toilettes. The scene was highly entertaining, and brought to mind the story of Le Diable Boiteux, unroofing the houses for the grat- ification of Don Cleofas. Jour- neg from India to England.

 A RUSSIAN AMAZON On dismounting at village near Darkee, my stirrup was held by fair and handsome-looking per- son, who proved to be female. Admira- ton of military life had induced her to deprive herself of her fair tresses, and to wear the dress of a man, preparatory as she said, to offering her services to the Emperor as a soldier. Hearing was on the way, she told me that, if she had been a little older, she e'would have accompanied me. I told her that she would be reject ed, from her feminine appearance; but she said she would cut off her breasts, when eversfhey were too large for conceaIment. On taking leave of this little amazon, I gave her an old aiguillette, which she ac- cepted with great delight, and strutted off with it on her shoulder, to the no small a. mazement of the villagers.-Ibid.

full articles.headline: WILLIAM BROWN, THE sAILoR.
full articles.article:
Dublin, of a female passenger who was dressed in sailors clothes, and passed by the name of William Brown. The officers. who took her into custody, acted from in- formation of the disguise, which they SUD- posed might have been done to conceal some theft. The sailor was conveyed to prison. From some enquiries, the house where Brown lodged was discovered, the proprietor of which referred the officers to the master of the brig Laura, of N. York, as Knowing all about her. Her story, as well as could be collected, appears to he as follows Her father is merchant in London. About 3 years ago she lief his house to follow her lover, who was the mate of vessel in the North American trade, and hearing he had sailed for St. Johns, she came to Liverpool and to ok passage for that port. On arriving at St. Johns, she discovered that the vessel had gone to Quebec, tilither she went, and there learned that her lover was drowned in his passage up the St. Lawrence. She immediately determined to become sai- Tor fer his sake, and assuming the garb of a man, engaged as cook and steward to the master of a vessel to London, with whom she remained upwards of 12 months.- The next vessel she joined, and in which she also served upwards of 12 months, some weeks back, brought her to Liver pool, but the master, suspecting her sex, extorted from her the secret, and wished her to remain with him, but she would net consent, and she was about to proceed to Ireland. While in prison she said her name was Selina Augusta Hamilton. She is said to be a complete sailor, taking her grog and using tobacco like other tars.- She states that she will have G4,OOO at her disposal when she becomes of age, (she is not yet 19) and intends to equip a vessel and take command. She was brought up for examination on the 10th Feb. at the Town Hall, when it appeared that her ar- rest was caused by the captain of the Lau- ra. The girl refused to tell the magistrate, Alderman Bourne, her fathers name she said she could see no. necessity for it: she said she was a sailor now, and such inten- ded to remain. MT. Duflrey, of the Lau- ra, wished the Magistrate to place her in his charge, that he might restore her to her father. At this sIre gave him look of surprise, and then remarked to the magis- trate, that she had made choice ofher pre- sent mode of life, and meant to pursue it. The magistrate discharged her.

 From the American Quarterly Review.

 ROMAN AMPHITHEATREs.

 Our author next brings us acqainted witII the aniphitheatres of the Romans, and pre- sents highly interesting picture eff the man. ner in which the " masters of the world" were recreated by the destruction of wild beasts, in the'circus. It was in the year 251, B. 0. that elephants were first introduced into the cireus,' by Metellus, berg those recently mentioned as captured in Sicily From this period, (says our author,) the passion for public ex- hibitions and combats of wild beasts, spread not only in Italy, but throughout the Roman empire in all the provinces" Such was the general rage, that scarcely a. fixed military station was without its circus or amphithea-' tre of turf or timber.

 The circular form of the amphitheatre was changed ny Julius Cesar for the elliptical, and thereafter such buildings were called theatres for hunting. They were also used for the combats of gladiators, as their acccommoda- tions were so much better than the circular buidings.-They were still however called circus, as often as by other names. Some were little more than notvral Ualleys, with benches cut in the surrounding hills others were elliptical excavations, with benches of turf like that near Sandwich in Kent; some were partly excavated, and partly construc- ted with masonry, like the amphitheatre at Caerlon in Britain. There were also amphi- theatres constructed to hold water for the combat of aquatic and amphibious animals. When these buildings were of timber, they were erected orremOved as occasion required. CapiOdorus states that Vespasian spent as much on one as would have built capital ci- ty; and Martial relates that Roman citizens crowded from all parts of the empire td be present at these exhibitions. .l

 The amphithcatres were supplied with wild beasts from the remotest provinces Of the ena- plre, and with :he most rare and singular ais- imals. without regard to their size or ferociots nature. Lions, tigers, bears. and hyenas, were brought, in what appears almost incredible numbers; the elephant, rhinoceros, hippopo- tamus. and camelOpard; stags and deer of every description; zebras, wild asses. ostrich and even the crocodile of the Nile, were all produced at different times & in various nnnn- bers to be exhibited IS objects of curiosity. to be hunted by the people in the theatre. or slaughtered in the combat with each other.

 The diversions were of three kinds In the first the anfphitheatre was cOnserted into a lrnslrespDtatiOn cf a natural f0fNsf hv 9neMuN Of

MELLEN, Sir--the cause of humanity siessassds Of me tn give the following state nent: My wife had for six years been in a decline and pronounced by her Physicians tn be in consumptiye state. and was attended by a severe pain in her side, with Cough & difficulty of breathing. She was reduced so low as to he unable to get from her bed to the fire without aid. All hopes of her recovery had long been given up. <, In this situation, was prevailed upon, as a last possible resort, vet without any hopes of success, to make aIsc of" Anderson's Cough Drops." She com mcnced the use of them in February last and after using two bottles, to the astonshment of all, in the month of May following the health of my wife was entirely restored, and since which, her health and strength were perhaps never better. Point oJf Honor.-One nsorning, while

 we were in Paris, our lacquey de place did

 not appear as usual. Breakfast passed, the carriage drove to the door,still no lacquey, and Colonel Clcaveland, in passion, had sent to engage another, when, panting with exertion, the gentleman appeared. "He

 was very sorry-he begged ten thousand

 pardons--he had hoped to have got his little affairs over sooner. " .' Your affairs, you scoundrel, what are your affairs to us- Do you think we are to sit waiting here, while you are running after your own affairs r. "Pardonnezmoi Monsieur" said the lacquey with. low bow, and laying his hand upon his heart, l" but it was an affair of honour !' and the man had actu- ally been fighting duel with swords, with

 another lacquey, in consequence ot some quarrel while waiting for us at the French
